Tol Brandir (also called the Tindrock) was one of the three peaks at the southern end of Nen Hithoel.  Unlike Amon Hen to the west or Amon Lhaw to the east
column2: Tol Brandir was an island; the Anduin split into two arms and flowed on both sides of the peak before rejoining and plunging over the falls of Rauros.  It was situated a little to the north of its companions and it was possible to paddle a boat across the river on it southern side above the waterfall. and

column1: It was said that no foot of man or beast had ever been set upon Tol Brandir
column2: which is understandable because its sides rose sheer out of the water.  High above the initial cliffs there were steep slopes with trees
column3: but then more grey cliffs shot up with a final spire of stone at the top.  Being inaccessible to other creatures
column4: many birds nested on the island.

column1: Tol Brandir is a Sindarin name meaning "Isle of the Great Steeples". Elements in the name are tol and brand (word)#Sindarin.

column2: the Mannish word for the island
column3: represents archaic Westron and contains the archaic English word tind spike.J.R.R. Tolkien noted that if tind had survived into modern speech
column4: it would have rhymed with find
column5: but it now appears as tine prong.
